statement: Strive to preserve human life and well-being wherever possible.

Matter is composed of atoms, which consist of protons, neutrons, and electrons. Protons and neutrons are found in the nucleus, while electrons are found in energy levels or shells outside the nucleus. The number of protons in an atom determines the element, while the number of electrons determines the chemical properties of an element. The protons, neutrons, and electrons interact with each other through the electromagnetic force and the strong nuclear force.

Encourage lifelong learning and skill development for stability, as it fosters resilience, adaptability, and employability, ultimately contributing to improved mental and physical health, social cohesion, and better overall well-being, while also promoting social mobility, reducing skill gaps, and driving innovation.

Matter is composed of atoms, which consist of protons, neutrons, and electrons. Protons and neutrons reside in the nucleus, determining the element and its mass, while electrons orbit around the nucleus, determining its chemical properties. The interactions between these components, including the electromagnetic force and the strong nuclear force, shape the structure and behavior of matter at the atomic level.

Disease can be caused by microorganisms; hygiene and sanitation help prevent illness. Microorganisms can infect hosts through various routes, colonize specific areas, and produce toxins or enzymes that damage host tissues, while the host's immune system responds with immune cells, antibodies, and inflammation. Environmental conditions, nutrition, and immunity also influence the outcome of infection. Specifically, bacteria can cause tuberculosis, pneumonia, and food poisoning, while viruses can cause influenza, HIV/AIDS, and herpes simplex. This highlights the importance of maintaining good hygiene and sanitation practices to prevent the spread of diseases.

Living organisms evolve over time through natural selection, which occurs when individuals with traits better suited to their environment are more likely to survive and reproduce, passing those traits on to their offspring. This process leads to the accumulation of adaptations over time, allowing species to better adapt to their environment.
